ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I was able to improve my ability to speak, write, and understand Spanish. We completed a lot of projects which taught me about various cultural and artistic concepts. The short stories, videos, and books we read and analyzed were, at times, challenging, but allowed me to grow my comprehension of Spanish.
I improved my ability to read, write, listen, and speak in Spanish.
I became a better Spanish writer and speaker.
I developed my grammar skills by taking this course.
I greatly improved my vocabulary and listening skills. My grammar and speaking skills also improved by a fair amount.
Intermediate spanish.
I learned how to speak spanish in a meaningful way. I improved my grammar a lot as well as my cultural understanding.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Professor Diaz was great and very helpful. He gave clear feedback that helped me improve my writing. The projects and assignments were interesting and explored a lot of different aspects of the culture of Spanish-speaking countries.

Weaknesses: The organization of the course could have been improved. We were not able to access an accurate syllabus as the assignments for my section did not exactly match the assignments listed in the syllabus for all SPAN 130 classes. At times there is a lot of busy work (particularly the supersite assignments).

The only significant weakness is disorganization. Sometimes, especially compared to my course last semester, it could be difficult to find which assignments were due at different points over the semester. The major strength was feedback. The instructor was always swift and abundant in the amount of feedback he gave, which helped my learning dramatically.
I would appreciate a more clear/coherent syllabus. The one we were given was reused from several semesters ago, and did not have accurate dates.

Senor Diaz was a fantastic instructor. The strengths were his flexibility and emphasis on growth rather than just grades. I would say a weakness of the course was I don't know if I improved in my speaking abilities but for sure improved with my writing.

Strengths:
- all in Spanish, this gave lots of practice time!
- there were plenty of reading materials to practice reading skills. 

Weaknesses:
- Assignments didnt usually didnt match up with what we were doing in class (on supersite). Sometimes had to read the book on my own to learn the grammar and then do the supersite
Weaknesses- doesnt teach grammar in a practical way, all learned by yourself
I think it's a little formulaic, and it's easy to not participate. However, it's a good time, and it helps you learn spanish
strengths: lots of interacting with classes, a variety of assignments lows: high workload

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! The course helped me improve my ability to speak and understand Spanish immensely.
This class definitely has a workload of 1.5 credits. This is something I would be weary of when signing up. It is taught very differently section to section.
Yes! It is a great way to improve your Spanish in an environment that rewards your growth.
Yes I would. The course is very challenging, but I learned a lot. The way the course is set up also makes it possible for people of a fairly wide range of skill levels to learn.
If needs be.
Yes because it is 1.5 credits and it wasn't that hard and you learn spanish.
